ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a more nuanced understanding of concepts like exploitation, slavery, economic injustice, etc. that are familiar and incredibly relevant.

More than anything, I think this course instilled in me the instinct to question structures (social, economic, political) that I take for granted or don't ever think about at all. It is difficult to be an informed and genuinely thoughtful citizen when you assume a priori that capitalism is the best system.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think this course has a lot of potential. The readings are really interesting and Professor Carico is extremely smart. However, I think the class could have been more structured with more input from the professor about the topics we should discuss. Becuase we did not have a lot of structure the conversations were often not as engaging or challenging as they could have been.

I think sometimes the reading was a bit much to be able to actually complete week to week, which is a challenge for optimal engagement with the class. I liked the fact that the class was small and people cared about the subject matter, so class discussion was always personal and engaging and lively.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Great class, interesting topics and great professor.

This course covers incredibly important topics, and does an amazing job showing how economic justice and racial justice are inseparable, so whether your interests fall more toward one or the other of those topics initially, this class is really illuminating. The syllabus was wide ranging and great, even though sometimes it was not possible to complete all the readings. Since the topic of the course is so broad and present in every area of life, it is easy to make it personal, relevant, and practical. It is also possible through the open ended assignments to focus on areas that are most interesting to you.
